comments.commentBody:
Talk about backing into the playoffs.

Somebody had to say it.
Sad that the Timbers won't be in as well.  They're fans deserve it.

It's too bad the Heisman can't consider a body of work.  Kellen Moore may not be the best player this year, but his career stats are pretty amazing.  On top of that, it would be nice to consider his coach.  When Boise St is ahead, Moore comes out so other quarterbacks can get playing time.  How does the Heisman panel look at that?.  Barry

First - I appreciate your opinion Big K, but you're clearly confused. Bucky will expose Sparty in much the same way they exposed Nebraska.

Second - Mike in Madison; please do not lump the rest of this state in with your misguided view of Badger fans. As I attend several games a year I can say that the student behavior is less than savory on game day. However, outside of that city it's a very different. Plus, as much as you might be heckled as a supporter of an opposing team, you are never in danger of being accosted or beaten...like you are in other stadiums.

Perhaps the Wisconsin student should be informed that their team will soon become part of the evil 1%ers when they go to the NFL, and so should be picketed and boycotted or forced to sign agreements to share their future earnings with their fellow students. A shame to see "progressive" Wisconsin support these fat cat violence-prone athletes; and the same with the Green Bay Packers. Oh, well, toast your hypocrisy with another bratwurst and beer.

Rhoden should stick to following New York (NY) teams as he's completely missed the point-
he's an underdog because he was drafted 7th round, regardless of his alma matter.

have you seen how many starting Bills are low draft picks or even undrafted players (ie Fred Jackson)?
that is the essence of being an underdog - no other teams really want you

I agree with one comment above that you don't hear often- Sanchez looks short out there, and has trouble seeing the whole field.
Also, he does seem to be very fidgety back there, and as soon as there is any pressure, forget about a long completion. He is looking for a quick out, or a run from the pocket (which can be successful).
Plus way too many innacurate throws to wide open receivers. And too many of his completions are to wide open guys. "Threading the needle" is not really in his vocabulary. I know it's a tough comparison, but if you saw Brady storm back to beat Dallas, and try and picture Sanchez making those type of throws......well, you can't.
He's not a complete bust, but given where they drafted him, what they are paying him, the opportunity cost of being built to "win now", well it seems that window has closed, and so you are left with a guy who is at or near his ceiling, which is an average QB.
So you have to ask yourself, if you are OK with an average QB. Not many teams win a SB with one, although about once or twice a decade it happens. Otherwise, you have to think about drafting your next "franchise" QB"
This is not news. Gender equality shouldn't be a factor in this election; this is the 20th century, and people should vote for the best candidate, regardless of his or her sex.

Of all the things to be worried about right now, exactly how many women are in the House and Senate seems almost like a ridiculous issue. A far bigger issue is what any member or proposed member of government is doing to help the country--regardless of gender, race, religion, sexual orientation, or anything else.

"Gender" bias is wrong, so is race bias. Let's talk about actions and accountablities.

What had the Democrats done the pass few years when they had the numbers? Nothing.

The Republican are nothing but corporate sellouts.

Why can we talk about their actions instead of parties. I'm so sick of both parties.

I'm all for anyone NEW, after all they can't do much worst than what we currently have.

Generally, I would say 'Let the best qualified person get the job regardless of anything else,' but getting into congress seems to have little to do with qualifications. It has to do with raising money (which is the downfall of American politics) and the perception of power and strength.  Women need a voice in law making and our voices are stifled by the money machine and the low value placed on female strengths.

The Times graph om women in the Senate would look even worse if Maine had not elected Margaret Chase Smith for four terms (1948-1972). Smith was a moderate Republican, like Snowe and Collins. It is very frustrating to read the negative comments here about the two female senators from Maine. I guess bipartisan politics is a thing of the past...at least in the near future.

When republican candidates of POTUS are saying that even birth control needs to be outlawed, we definitely do need to have more women in congress to stop this kind of control of women and women's bodies.

If Democrats have a bad year it will not just be omen in congress who have a bad year. Women throughout the United States will see their rights curbed if there is a republicon tea bag majority. If there is any of the yahoos currently in the gop lineup for prez it would be even worse.

And women would not be the only losers if the gop does well. The entire nation will be hurt, including the 1% who have been siphoning off our wealth for the last three decades since the reaganist devolution started. WE will se the middle clas essentially cease to exist, the US become a second rate world power, Taliban like restricitions on personal liberty, and a handing over of the riegns of all economic power to mega corporations. THAT is the tea party republcion vision for America.

#22 put it far more eloquently than I could, but yes, unfortunately, gender is still an issue, much as women, most of all, would like it put to rest. For all the educational strides made by women -- which are, interestingly enough, a consequence of discrimination and gender based stereotyping in the workplace because, absent a science or math degree, college trained women were (before these jobs were eliminated) funneled off into clerical and secretarial work at a greater clip than their male contemporaries. Women literally HAD to go to grad school, for the slightest chance of parity. And in this economy, like everything else, nothing improved.

I'm certainly not of the easy opinions of one gender being better at the other, whether in a particular area or overall, but again, this may be one of those situations where the law of unintended consequences took effect. For 3-4 decades women have been pushed to excel in work, play, education, looks, personality, childrearing, obligations to the family, etc. -- most ALL AT ONCE. For many women it's not an issue of a promotion, or a raise (still the 73 cents on a man's dollar!), but of breaking even, of what absolutely must be done. All the discrimination created so much pressure that it raised a couple of generations of lock step, highly disciplined human beings who have little idea of how to behave otherwise. Why not strike while the iron is hot and put more women in government who were brought up this way?

(It isn't to say that in say, another 2-3 generations when the old girl's network gets going women aren't going to get flabby and smug, but for now...)

I know it's considered "identity politics" and gauche to speak in this way, but there's truth to what I say.

To those wondering why more women don't run, here's one person's opinion.  I was asked to run  in a local election and declined.  I am well educated, experienced and involved in the community - I think I could have done a good job.  However, my entire life simply could not have stood up to public scrutiny - although any ( and very long ago) transgressions were certainly no worse than the men running for this office.  However, I think women are held to a much different standard and I would never expose my family to the inevitable attacks.

If you want the Free Market to function again, you can't just step back and magically hope it will work through "invisible hand waving".  You need  to break up the "too big to fail" institutions, so that they are not that big any more, so we can let them fail without taking the rest of us down with them. And bundled mortages need to be abolished not regulated. If the person authorizing the loan will sell it to a sucker afterwards, there is no incentive to make sure it is a safe loan, and we get the result we got in 2008. The risk is too great, and the benefits are essentially negligible, to everyone but those who do the bundling.

Why should banking be a profitable enterprise? Banks do not, as a rule, use stockholder money to fund the the lending. They use government and savers money for funding lending. They are supplying neither capital nor ingenuity in their business. Their profits and payroll should be ordinary. They do not rule the universe nor improve it.
Why use a bank at all.  Join a credit union and keep the money in the community.
If banks don't want to be regulated I say fine go ahead and take down the FDIC stickers on the front of the buildings they won't last 48hrs!
Not even a mention of Fannie and Freddie. Who do you think bought all the mortgages that the banks originated from Federal money? People need to wake up.

I don't agree that the killing of Qaddafi (assuming he was shot while in captivity), of itself, indicates a lack of readiness for democracy. The French chopped off the head of Maria Antoinette, but they finally got their act together. killing Qaddafi was a political necessity. Alive, he would inspire continued counter-revolutionary activity. The only way to put a period at the end of that sentence was to put a bullet in his head -- then tell the press he was shot while trying to escape.

I do agree that what's happening in Egypt raise questions about how long, if ever, previously oppressed people will take to make the same progress the French do, or we in the US.
Sure beats George W. bush's repeated trips to Congress to get "supplemental budgets" which doubled our national debt.
I'm hoping to hear an announcement from his press representative real soon, telling us that Gadhafi will continue to fight on, even though he's dead.
good news for people living in this world who desire for peace and human rights.
